contentrichtext.text: [[File:Zaharia Stancu.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Stancu sometime during the Cold War]] '''Zaharia Stancu''' ({{IPA-ro|zahaˈri.a ˈstanku}}; October 7, 1902 – December 5, 1974) was a [[Romanian people|Romanian]] prose writer, novelist, poet, and philosopher. Stancu was born in 1902 in [[Salcia, Teleorman|Salcia]], a village in [[Teleorman County]], [[Romania]]. After leaving school at the age of thirteen he worked at various jobs. In 1921, with the help of [[Gala Galaction]], he became a journalist. In 1933 he finished his studies in literature and philosophy at the [[University of Bucharest]]. His fist volume of poetry, ''Poeme simple'' (''Simple Poems''), appeared in 1927, receiving the Romanian Writers' Prize. During [[World War II]], he was imprisoned for his opposition to the [[Fascism|fascist]] government of [[Ion Antonescu]] (''see [[Romania during World War II]]''), and spent time in the [[Târgu Jiu]] [[Internment|internment camp]] for [[political prisoner]]s. In 1946, he became a director of [[National Theatre Bucharest|Romania's National Theater]]. After the [[Communist Romania|Communist regime]] was established, he was a member of the [[Romanian Academy]] and the President of the [[Writers Union of Romania|Writers' Union of Romania]] (1966–1974). He won the Romanian State Prize for Literature and, in 1971, he was awarded the [[Herder Prize]] by the [[Austria]]n government. Between 1926 and 1944 Stancu published six volumes of poetry. In 1948 his first important novel, ''Desculț'' (''Barefoot''), was published. It has been translated into thirty languages. Other important novels are ''Şatra'' (''The Gypsy Tribe''), and ''Jocul cu moartea'' (''A Gamble with Death''). ==References== *{{ro icon}} [http://www.observatorul.com/articles_main.asp?action=articleviewdetail&ID=186] Venera E.
